columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about equity as an option.

To start with, let us define options.

**Options** are types of financial contracts which give the holder the right, but not the obligation to buy or sell a specific asset at a predetermined price, on or before its date of expiration.

Here are the parameters to solve the problem: 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Asset's Value |$1,040 | 
| Risk-free interest rate (r) |4.80% | 
|Face Value (FV) of Debt |$1,000 | 
|Minimum Possible Value of Assets    |$940  |
|Maximum Possible Value of Assets    |$1,270  |

## Requirement A

We are asked to solve the value of the company's equity and the value of the debt.

To start with, let us invest the value of the minimum possible value of assets at the end of the year in the risk-free asset. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Asset's Value}&=\frac{\text{Minimum Possible Value}}{\left(1+\text{r}\right)}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$940}{\left(1+0.048\right)}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$940}{1.048}\\[20pt]
&=\$869.95
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the replicated value of assets of the firm is $869.95.

Now, if the assets turn out to be $1,270, the maximum possible price at the end of the year, then the value of option is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Value of Option}&=\text{Maximum Possible Value}-\text{FV of Debt}\\[15pt]
&=\$1,270-1,000\\[15pt]
&=\$270
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the option is worth $270 if the assets turn out to be $1,270.

The risk-free asset will be worth $940, the minimum possible value, so we need this value of call option as below: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Value of Option}&=\frac{\left(\text{Maximum-Minimum}\right)}{\text{Value of Option}}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\left(\$1,270-\$940\right)}{\$270}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$330}{\$270}\\[15pt]
&=1.22
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, we will need 1.22 call options if the risk-free asset will be worth $940.

## Requirement B

We are asked to solve the value of the company's equity and the value of the debt if the assets will be worth $850 or $1,750 in a year.

First, let us invest the value of the minimum possible value of assets at the end of the year in the risk-free asset. 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Asset's Value}&=\frac{\text{Minimum Possible Value}}{\left(1+\text{r}\right)}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$850}{\left(1+0.048\right)}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$850}{1.048}\\[20pt]
&=\$811.07
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the replicated value of assets of the firm is $811.07.

Now, if the assets turn out to be $1,750, the maximum possible price at the end of the year, then the value of the option is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Value of Option}&=\text{Maximum Possible Value}-\text{FV of Debt}\\[15pt]
&=\$1,750-1,000\\[15pt]
&=\$750
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the option is worth $750 if the assets turn out to be $1,750.

The risk-free asset will be worth $850, the minimum possible value, so we need this value of call option as below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Value of Option}&=\frac{\left(\text{Maximum-Minimum}\right)}{\text{Value of Option}}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\left(\$1,750-\$850\right)}{\$750}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$900}{\$750}\\[15pt]
&=1.20
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, we will need 1.20 call options if the risk-free asset will be worth $850.
The stockholders may opt to invest more if the assets will be $850 or $1,750 in a year. The resulting value of equity is higher in this scenario, hence stockholders will favor this move.
